title: Do schools kill creativity? - Sir Ken Robinson

multiple-choice.question: What are the three themes running through the conference that the speaker finds relevant to his talk about education and creativity?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The role of teachers, the impact of social media, and the value of standardized testing.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because we don't value the arts and humanities.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we don't have enough time to devote to creative activities.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the difference between the way we think about intelligence and the way it actually is?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Intelligence is diverse, dynamic, and distinct.

options.label: C
options.text: Intelligence is only related to academic ability.

options.label: D
options.text: Intelligence is only related to physical ability.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story that the speaker tells about Gillian Lynne, a choreographer who went on to create successful musical theater productions?

options.label: A
options.text: Gillian Lynne was a talented dancer from a young age and went on to become a successful choreographer.

options.label: B
options.text: Gillian Lynne was diagnosed with a learning disorder and was told to calm down, but instead she found her passion for dance.

options.label: C
options.text: Gillian Lynne was a failed student who went on to become a successful businesswoman.

options.label: D
options.text: Gillian Lynne was a professional athlete who turned to dance as a hobby.

multiple-choice.question: What is the quote from Jonas Salk that the speaker mentions, and what does it illustrate?

options.label: A
options.text: "If all the insects were to disappear from the Earth, within 50 years, all life on Earth would end." This illustrates the importance of preserving biodiversity.

options.label: B
options.text: "If all human beings were to disappear from the Earth, within 50 years, all forms of life would flourish." This illustrates the impact of human activity on the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: "We have to be careful now that we use our gift wisely." This illustrates the importance of responsible use of technology.

options.label: D
options.text: "Our education system has mined our minds in the way that we strip-mine the earth for a particular commodity." This illustrates the need to rethink our approach to education.

title: Can you solve the counterfeit coin riddle? - Jennifer Lu

multiple-choice.question: A mathematician is tasked with identifying a counterfeit coin among 12 identical coins. He has a balance scale and can use it only three times. How does he identify the counterfeit coin?

options.label: A
options.text: By weighing each coin against all of the others.

options.label: B
options.text: By dividing the 12 coins into three equal piles of four and marking the authentic coins with a zero.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a special machine to detect the counterfeit coin.

options.label: D
options.text: By relying on his intuition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the mathematician's marker in the task of identifying the counterfeit coin?

options.label: A
options.text: To write a poem about the task.

options.label: B
options.text: To mark the authentic coins with a zero.

options.label: C
options.text: To record the results of each weighing.

options.label: D
options.text: To solve a math problem.

multiple-choice.question: If the two sides of the balance scale do not balance after the first weighing, what should the mathematician do?

options.label: A
options.text: Weigh the coins again, but this time against different coins.

options.label: B
options.text: Mark the coins on the heavier side with a plus and those on the lighter side with a minus.

options.label: C
options.text: Call for a second chance to use the balance scale.

options.label: D
options.text: Give up and admit defeat.

multiple-choice.question: How can the mathematician determine which of the remaining coins is the counterfeit coin in the case where the previously heavier side became lighter after the substitution?

options.label: A
options.text: By weighing two of the minus coins against each other.

options.label: B
options.text: By weighing two of the plus coins against each other.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a different method to identify the counterfeit coin.

options.label: D
options.text: By asking for help from someone else.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the mathematician's task in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To win a prize for solving the problem.

options.label: B
options.text: To impress the emperor with his math skills.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the counterfeit coin and earn his freedom.

options.label: D
options.text: To solve a math problem for the sake of solving it.

title: Why all world maps are wrong

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that map makers face when trying to represent the surface of a sphere as a plane?

options.text: The surface of a sphere cannot be represented as a plane without some form of distortion.

options.label: B
options.text: The surface of a sphere can be represented as a plane without any distortion.

options.label: C
options.text: The surface of a sphere can be represented as a plane with some form of distortion, but it's not a big deal.

options.label: D
options.text: The surface of a sphere cannot be represented as a plane at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the projection that is popular for navigation, and preserves direction, but distorts size?

options.label: B
options.text: Gall-Peters projection

options.label: C
options.text: Winkel tripel projection

options.label: D
options.text: Cylindrical projection

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the problems with the Mercator projection?

options.label: A
options.text: It distorts shape, but preserves size.

options.label: B
options.text: It preserves shape, but distorts size.

options.label: C
options.text: It preserves direction, but distorts shape.

options.label: D
options.text: It preserves size, but distorts direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the projection that is called an equal-area map, and preserves area, but distorts shape?

options.label: A
options.text: Mercator projection

options.label: B
options.text: Gall-Peters projection

options.label: C
options.text: Winkel tripel projection

options.label: D
options.text: Cylindrical projection

options.label: B
options.text: Map makers started using new materials to create maps.

options.label: C
options.text: Cartographers started using new software to create maps.

options.label: D
options.text: The National Geographic Society adopted a new projection.

title: Why Don't Ants Get Stuck In Traffic?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why ants do not get stuck in traffic jams, despite having crowded roads?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too small to see each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too slow to react to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they get organized and use lanes to navigate.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they do not have to worry about losing their food.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people tend to hate traffic, even when it's not caused by a specific incident?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are anxious about being late.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are uncertain about the cause of the delay.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they hate waiting in line.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are bored.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the psychological illusions that people experience on the road, related to traffic?

options.label: A
options.text: The illusion that the other lane is moving faster.

options.label: B
options.text: The illusion that they are not being passed by other cars.

options.label: C
options.text: The illusion that they are spending more time being passed than passing.

options.label: D
options.text: The illusion that they are the only one on the road.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key differences between human drivers and leaf-cutter ants when it comes to traffic?

options.label: A
options.text: Human drivers are faster and more efficient than ants.

options.label: B
options.text: Human drivers are more cooperative and work together like ants.

options.label: C
options.text: Human drivers are more individualistic and focused on their own goals.

options.label: D
options.text: Human drivers are more patient and willing to wait.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential solution to the problem of traffic, according to the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Building more roads and increasing the speed limit.

options.label: B
options.text: Implementing a system of self-driving cars optimized to serve the collective good.

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the number of traffic lights and intersections.

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging people to drive more aggressively.

title: The neuroscience of imagination - Andrey Vyshedskiy

multiple-choice.question: According to the Hebbian principle, what happens when neurons fire together?

options.label: A
options.text: They weaken their connections.

options.label: B
options.text: They become disconnected.

options.label: C
options.text: They strengthen their connections.

options.label: D
options.text: They die off.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Mental Synthesis Theory's explanation for how the brain can create new, complex images?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves the simultaneous activation of multiple neuronal ensembles in the posterior cortex.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves the prefrontal cortex sending electrical signals to multiple ensembles in the posterior cortex.

options.label: C
options.text: It involves the posterior cortex firing signals to the prefrontal cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves the simultaneous activation of a single neuronal ensemble.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of myelin in neural fibers?

options.label: A
options.text: It slows down electrical signals.

options.label: B
options.text: It insulates and speeds up electrical signals.

options.label: C
options.text: It disconnects neural fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: It strengthens neural connections.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Mental Synthesis Theory, what is necessary for mental synthesis to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: The simultaneous activation of multiple neuronal ensembles.

options.label: B
options.text: The prefrontal cortex sending electrical signals to multiple ensembles in the posterior cortex.

options.label: C
options.text: The posterior cortex firing signals to the prefrontal cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: The simultaneous activation of a single neuronal ensemble.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between neural fibers with thicker layers of myelin and those with thinner layers?

options.label: A
options.text: The length of the connections.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of layers of myelin.

options.label: C
options.text: The conduction velocity of electrical signals.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of neurons connected.
